items.content:
Welcome to the sixth theme of English
This theme is about School.

How are you going to practise?
You are going to practise your writing, reading, listening and speaking skills.
You will visit websites, play games, do exercises and listen to stories.

What are you going to do?
You are going to read, listen, speak and write about school and many things related to it.
By practising a lot your English will improve!

Have fun!

You have just started the theme School.
You will find different things to watch, to listen to, to read and of course to do.
There are videos, recordings, pictures, photos, texts and assignments.
There are different types of assignments. Some of them you have to do on your own, others you are doing in a group.

At the end of those group assignments you are going to discuss the answers in your group. Some assignment will be checked by the computer.
First, you are going to do a test to see if you are ready to start this theme.

content.body:
Fill in the right words in the right sentences.

reading - teachers/professors - in most countries - to learn - pupils/students

School is a place where people go .
In a school, one or more help with learning.
Today, children have to go to school for a number of years,
so that they can learn the most important things, such as ,
writing, and some basic math.

items.content:
In this theme you will focus on the following 'can do' statements.
In dit thema ga je je richten op de volgende leerdoelen.

Luisteren

  • Je kunt vertrouwde woorden en basiszinnen begrijpen die te maken hebben met het thema School, wanneer de mensen langzaam en duidelijk spreken.

Lezen

  • Je kunt eenvoudige zinnen in een eenvoudig verhaaltje begrijpen. Bijvoorbeeld in mededelingen, posters en korte teksten uit het thema School.

Gesprekken voeren

  • Je kunt deelnemen aan een eenvoudig gesprek over school. Je gesprekspartner spreekt vrij langzaam. Hij of zij herhaalt af en toe zinnen. Je gesprekspartner helpt bij het formuleren van wat jij probeert te zeggen. Je kunt eenvoudige vragen stellen en beantwoorden over het thema School.

Spreken

  • Je kunt eenvoudige uitdrukkingen en zinnen gebruiken om iets te vertellen over jouw school, lesrooster en vakkenpakket.

Schrijven

  • Je kunt een kort, eenvoudig verhaaltje schrijven met de woorden die betrekking hebben op het thema School. Bijvoorbeeld over jouw lesrooster of jouw favoriete schoolvak.

In this theme you are going to do the following things:

  • Will have listened to people talking about school routines, school subjects and school objects;
  • Will have read texts about someone's timetable, school subjects, school supplies, someone's experience going to secondary school and someone's experience learning a language;
  • Will have written about your school and your timetable and your favourite subject;
  • Will have talked about your school, your experiences at school and your timetable;
  • Will have practised school-related vocabulary;
  • Will have learned and practised question words and the past simple for regular verbs;
  • Will have learned more about the British and American school systems.

But you don't have to be able to do this right away!
If you take the following steps you'll find out what you need to know!

Lesson Title Activity
1 School supplies

Listen to a conversation about buying school supplies, read a text about a problem on an American school, talk and write about buying school supplies.

Grammar: 'interrogatives'
2 Lunch Break

Listen to a video about preparing school lunch, read a text about a timetable, talk and write about your timetable.

Grammar: 'past simple'
3 Back to school

Listen to a video about preparations for the new school year, read a text about the first day at a new school, talk and write about your first day at school.

Grammar: 'past simple'
4 School subjects

Listen to a song about school subjects, read a text about favourite school subjects, talk and write about your favourite subject.

Grammar: 'grammar test'

Links vind je de vier blokken die horen bij dit thema.
Maak je keuze: "School supplies", "Lunch Break", "Back to school" en "School subjects".

Blok 1

School supplies
Blok 2

Lunch Break
Blok 3

Back to school
Blok 4

School subjects

Vocabulary School

Hieronder vind je woordenlijsten en lijsten met zinnen (chunks) die horen bij dit thema.
Deze komen ook terug in de diagnostische toets. Overleg met je docent wanneer je deze lijsten gaat leren.

Vocabularylist School A School chunks A
Vocabularylist School B School chunks B
Vocabularylist School C

Tip:

There are many ways to study vocabulary. You can read the words aloud or copy them.
Click in StudioWozzol on the red arrow for the options.
Er zijn veel manieren om te werken aan je woordenschat. Je kunt de woorden hardop uitspreken of kopiëren.
Klik in StudioWozzol op de rode pijl voor de verschillende opties.

The subject of this double period is school supplies.

  • Make groups of three or four.
  • In your group, discuss the following questions in English:
    • What kind of supplies do you need for school? Think of things that you've got in your bag or your pencil case, but also electronic devices.
    • Do you spend a lot of money on school supplies? Explain your answer.
    • Do you argue about the price of school supplies with your parents?
Step activiteit
activity		 leerdoel
aim		 tijd
time
introduction Find out what you already know. 10
Step 1 listening
School supplies		 You can understand a conversation about buying school supplies and answer questions. 15
Step 2 reading
Going broke		 You can understand a text about the rising cost of school supplies and answer questions. 15
Step 3 vocabulary You can understand and use the vocabulary about school and school supplies. 15
Step 4 grammar
interrogatives		 You can understand and use interrogatives. 15
Step 5

speaking
Bargaining for school supplies

 You can have a conversation in which you bargain for school supplies. 10
Step 6 writing
Write an opinion piece		 You can write an opinion piece about the cost of school supplies. 15
Step 7 evaluation Reflecting on what you have learnt. 05

School supplies

You are going to listen to a conversation between a girl and her father about buying school supplies.

  • Listen to the conversation.
  • While listening, think about the following questions:
    • What can you say about the father's tone?
    • What can you say about the daughter's tone?

Do the exercises.

prompt.body: 1. What school supplies does the daughter want?

content.body: A calculator, a palm pilot and a laptop.
Pencils, an eraser and a ruler.
Online learning materials.

prompt.body: 2. What argument does the father use to tell his daughter he doesn't want to buy them?

content.body: Electronic gadgets like that are far too expensive.
He managed to get through school without all that stuff.
Nobody in middle school has electronic gadgets like that.

prompt.body: 3. With what argument does the daughter react?

content.body: Dad always went to school by car.
Dad is just being old-fashioned.
The school offers to help pay for supplies.

prompt.body:
4. Dad says the daughter isn't getting a computer unless she convinces her mother to 'sell the car'.
What does he want to make clear by that?

content.body: Having a car is more important than having a computer.
She can have a computer if her mother sells the car.
They can't afford to buy an expensive laptop computer.

prompt.body: 5. What arguments does the daughter use to convince her father to buy her a calculator? Select the four correct answers.

content.body: She promises to clean up her room.
She promises to help pay for it.
She promises to take care of her dad in his old age.
She reminds him he wants her to do well in school.
She tells him they can get one at a discount.
They can buy it cheaply online.

prompt.body: 6. If they do everything the girl suggests, how much will the calculator eventually cost her dad?
7. Is the girl going to get an ice cream? Why (not)?

content.body: No, because her mom and dad are already going to buy her an expensive calculator.
No, because she was only getting one if she convinced her dad to buy her everything she asked for.
Yes, because her dad is so impressed with her bargaining skills that he is going to buy her one.
Yes, because her mom promised her one of she could convince her dad to buy her a calculator today.

prompt.body:
Work with a classmate. Discuss the following questions, some of which are from the introduction:

  1. What can you say about the father's tone?
  2. What can you say about the daughter's tone?
  3. What do you think of the daughter's bargaining skills? Explain your answer.

values.value:
Examples:

  1. It’s sarcastic.
  2. It’s also pretty sarcastic.
  3. I think they’re really good. I think the calculator was the only thing she really wanted, but by asking for a laptop and a palm pilot as well, she was making just the calculator look like a good deal. And she used very convincing arguments – she clearly did her research.

content.body:
Examples:

  1. It's sarcastic.
  2. It's also pretty sarcastic.
  3. I think they're really good. I think the calculator was the only thing she really wanted, but by asking for a laptop and a palm pilot as well, she was making just the calculator look like a good deal. And she used very convincing arguments - she clearly did her research.

items.content:
You are going to read an article about the cost of school supplies.

  • Read the article.
  • While reading, think about the following questions:
    • What is the problem? Describe it in one sentence.
    • What two solutions are mentioned in the text?

Going broke sending the kids back to school? Average cost of school supplies tops $100

By Rebecca Dube

If the words "school supplies" call to mind a few pencils, a notebook, maybe a Trapper Keeper, get ready for the new math: The average K-12* parent will spend $100 per student on school supplies this year, up 12 percent from last year.

And that might be getting off easy. If parents like Kimberly Brown of Salinas, California, bought everything on her child's list, the tab could be as much as $400.

"It seems like it gets more and more and more expensive," Brown told NBC's Janet Shamlian. "It seems like they're asking for way too much stuff."

School supply lists that schools give to parents for fall may include high-tech items like graphing calculators and flash drives; but they also expect parents to shell out for things like staplers, hand sanitizer, paper plates, even ice cube trays.

Teachers say these lists are just suggestions, and they're not required of anyone.

"There's nothing said to anyone who doesn't bring it," teacher Terese Boronda said.

Often, in fact, teachers are the ones who end up spending their hard-earned money on school supplies for their classes.

At Tampa's "Twice As Nice" consignment shop, parents can buy new or gently used school supplies at a lower cost.

Two former teachers opened the store after years of spending hundreds of dollars of their own money on supplies.

"I think people take for granted that it just magically appears in their classroom, but it doesn't," explains Twice as Nice owner Adrianne Wilson.

And school supplies are just part of the back-to-school tab. Add in clothing, shoes and electronics, and the average cost of sending a child to back to class this year is $669.

[Source: https://www.today.com/parents/school-supplies-average-cost-tops-100-1D80069506]

*K-12: education between the ages of 4 and 16 (Kindergarten to 12th grade)

Do the exercises.

prompt.body: 1. By how much have the costs of school supplies gone up compared to last year?
2. Who makes the list that Kimberly Brown talks about? Explain your answer.

values.value: The school. At first it looks like it’s the child itself, but in the 4th paragraph it becomes clear that it’s a school supply list ‘that schools give to parents’.

content.body: The school. At first it looks like it's the child itself, but in the 4th paragraph it becomes clear that it's a school supply list 'that schools give to parents'.

prompt.body: 3. Do parents have to buy everything that's on the list? Explain your answer.

values.value: No. Teachers say that ‘these lists are just suggestions, and they're not required of anyone’. They also say that nothing is going to happen if a student doesn’t bring all the items that are on the list.

content.body: No. Teachers say that 'these lists are just suggestions, and they're not required of anyone'. They also say that nothing is going to happen if a student doesn't bring all the items that are on the list.

prompt.body: 4. Who buys the school supplies if parents don't?

content.body: The teachers.

prompt.body: 5. How do Adrienne Wilson and her colleague try to solve the problem?

values.value: They have a store where you can buy school supplies cheaply or second-hand.

content.body: They have a store where you can buy school supplies cheaply or second-hand.

prompt.body: 6. What makes school even more expensive for parents, according to the text?

content.body: clothing, shoes and electronics

prompt.body:
Work with a classmate. Discuss the following questions, some of which are from the introduction:

  1. What is the problem? Describe it in one sentence.
  2. What two solutions are mentioned in the text?
  3. The text gives some examples of things that are on school supply lists. What do you think of them? Should schools ask parents to pay for them or not?

values.value:
1. School supplies are becoming more and more expensive.
  2. You don’t have to buy everything that’s on the list, and there is a special store where you can buy school supplies more cheaply.
  3. Example: I think it’s OK to ask parents to pay for calculators, flash drives and staplers, but the school should pay for hand sanitizer. Paper plates and ice cube trays are unnecessary, so you shouldn’t buy those.

content.body:
1. School supplies are becoming more and more expensive.
  2. You don't have to buy everything that's on the list, and there is a special store where you can buy school supplies more cheaply.
  3. Example: I think it's OK to ask parents to pay for calculators, flash drives and staplers, but the school should pay for hand sanitizer. Paper plates and ice cube trays are unnecessary, so you shouldn't buy those.

items.content:
To be able to do all the assignments correctly, you need to know some words and sentences.
For each theme there are word lists ready in Wozzol, with which you can practice:

Woordenlijst School Supplies hv12
  • Study the vocabulary. (10 minutes)
  • Do the exercise.

Tip!
There are many ways to study vocabulary. You can read the words aloud or copy them. The most important rule is never to spend more than 10 minutes studying words. Every minute you spend longer is a waste of time.

content.body:
Which word fits the description? There are three extra words.
Choose from: calculator - classroom - eraser - glue - notebook - pen - principal - required - ruler - scissors - suggestion - supplies - textbook.

  1. a kind of book you can write in
  2. a machine you need for maths
  3. a stick with ink in it, used for writing
  4. all the things you need for school
  5. something you say, but which someone else doesn't have to do
  6. the person who runs the school
  7. the place where you have lessons
  8. you can use this to make straight lines
  9. you use this to stick things together
  10. you use this when you write in pencil and you've made a mistake

items.content:
Interrogatives (vraagwoorden) zijn woorden waarmee je een vraag kunt beginnen.

Voorbeelden:

What is that? - Wat is dat?
Who are you? - Wie ben jij?

Bestudeer uit de Kennisbank Engels het onderdeel Vraagwoorden. Denk na over deze vragen:

  • Kun je het verschil uitleggen tussen what en which?
  • Kun je nog een voorbeeld bedenken waarin je in het Nederlands een ander vraagwoord gebruikt dan in het Engels?
Vraagwoorden
Do the exercise.

content.body:
Fill in the correct interrogative.

1. has got a paper round? Your brother?

Fill in the correct interrogative.

2. animal is black and white? - A zebra.

Fill in the correct interrogative.

3. do you live? - In London.

Fill in the correct interrogative.

4. is the next train to Manchester? - At 9.15 am.

Fill in the correct interrogative.

5. do you prefer, pizza or pasta?

Fill in the correct interrogative.

6. did the Titanic sink? - It hit an iceberg.

Fill in the correct interrogative.

7. are the curtains closed? - Because the light is bothering me.

Fill in the correct interrogative.

8. are they going next? Amsterdam or Brussels?

Fill in the correct interrogative.

9. is this flower called? - It's a rose.

Fill in the correct interrogative.

10. can I get you? - Coffee, please.

items.content:
Bargaining for school supplies

Have a discussion with a classmate. Use the description below.

Preparation

  1. If you want, you can do some research on the internet on bargaining techniques. You can also use the listening input from step 1 as an example.
  2. Decide on one or more bargaining tricks you want to use.
  3. Write down what you (don't) want, plus your arguments.
  4. Write down a couple of words and phrases to help you in your discussion.

Having the discussion

  1. Find another pair to work with.
  2. Have your discussion.
  3. Ask your classmates to write down feedback for you.
  4. Next, let them have their discussion and write down feedback for them.
  5. Discuss what went well and what you can do better next time.

Je hebt allerlei dingen gezien die je heel graag wilt hebben voor school - maar alles bij elkaar is het nogal duur. Je gaat daarom proberen je vader of moeder (gespeeld door je klasgenoot) te overtuigen het voor je te kopen.

Gebruik alle onderhandelingstrucs die je kunt bedenken om de ander te overtuigen. Praat ongeveer 2 minuten.

Write an opinion piece

You have read a text about the rising cost of school supplies. Now you are going to write an opinion piece.

  • Think about the following questions and make notes:
    • What, in your opinion, are school supplies that every student should have?
    • Who should pay for them?
    • How do you deal with parents who can't afford to buy school supplies for their children?
  • Write an opinion piece, using your notes.
    • Start with a short introduction in which you explain the problem.
    • State your opinion and support it with arguments.
    • Finish with a conclusion.
  • Ask your teacher how many words you have to use.

What have you learnt in this double period?
Answer the following questions:

  • What was the easiest part of this lesson?
  • What did you already know?
  • What was the most difficult part?
  • What was new to you in this lesson?
  • Are there things you don't quite understand yet? How are you going to deal with them?
  • What do you need to ask your teacher?

The subject of this double period is your timetable.

  • Make groups of three or four.
  • Discuss these questions in English with your group:
  • Wich subjects on your timetable do you like or dislike? Explain why.
    • What do you do during the breaks?
    • What do you eat for lunch? And where does your lunch come from? Home, the cafeteria, the supermarket?
    • What do you think about your timetable in general?
Step activiteit
activity		 leerdoel
aim		 tijd
time
introduction Find out what you already know. 10
Step 1 reading
Jason's timetable 		You can understand a text about a timetable and answer questions. 15
Step 2 listening
Healthy lunch ideas for school		 You can understand a video about preparing a healthy school lunch and answer questions. 15
Step 3 vocabulary You can understand and use vocabulary about timetables and breaks. 15
Step 4 grammar
Past simple		 You can understand and use the past simple. 15
Step 5 speaking
Your school day		 You can have a conversation about your timetable. 10
Step 6 writing
A diary entry about your timetable		 You can write a diary entry about your timetable. 15
Step 7 evaluation Reflecting on what you have learnt. 05

Jason's timetable

You are going to read a text about Jason's timetable.

  • Read the text. While reading, think about the following questions:
    • Do you know what all the names of the subjects mean? If not, look them up.
    • Are there any subjects that Jason has that you don't have?
    • Are there also subjects that you have, but that Jason doesn't have?

Jason's timetable

Jason goes to school from Monday to Friday. He has got ten different subjects at his school. Every day, the first period is free. Lunch break is always after the fourth period.

On Monday, Jason starts with History, followed by maths and biology. After the lunch break he goes to chemistry, then economics and he ends the day with self-defense.

On Tuesday, the morning lessons are languages, art and chemistry. In the afternoon Jason has biology and technology. Just as on Monday, he ends the day with self-defense.

On Wednesday Jason's school day starts with maths, followed by economics and self-defense. After the lunch break Jason has history and languages. At the end of the day he has his favourite subject, P.E. - which is short for physical education.

On Thursday morning his timetable starts with biology, chemistry and P.E. The three lessons in the afternoon are technology, maths and art.

Friday is the last school day of the week. The morning lessons start with history, art and P.E. After lunch break Jason goes to languages and technology. He ends his school week with economics.

Do the exercises.

prompt.body:
Read the text and complete Jason's timetable.

Monday Tuesdag Wednesday Thursday Friday
1
2
3
4
5
6
7

content.body:
Monday Tuesdag Wednesday Thursday Friday
1 History Languages Math Biology History
2 History Languages Math Biology History
3 Math Art Economics Chemistry Art
4 Biology Chemistry Self-Defense P.E P.E
5 Chemistry Biology History Technology Languages
6 Economics Technology Languages Math Technology
7 Self-Defense Self-Defense P.E Art Economics

Are the statements true or false? Choose the correct answers.

1. Jason goes to school four days a week. True / False
2. Jason has Chemistry three times a week. True / False
3. On Wednesday, Jason's Languages class is before lunch. True / False
4. On Friday, Jason's Economics class is before his Technology class. True / False
5. Jason's Self Defense class is the last class of the day on Mondays and Tuesdays. True / False
6. Jason's Art class is his first class on Thursdays. True False
7. All of Jason's school days are the same length. True / False
8. Jason does not study any foreign languages. True / False

items.content:
Healthy lunch ideas for school

You are going to watch a video by Aspyn Ovard about healthy school lunches.

  • Watch the video.
  • While watching, think about the following questions:
    • Which of these lunches do you like best?
    • If you were to bring these lunches, would you be eating more healthily than usual?

prompt.body: Make notes while watching. Write down in short what is on the menu for each school day.

values.value:
Monday: peanut butter / jelly sandwich, apple, cellery, carrots and ranch sauce.

Tuesday: spinach and lettuce salad with strawberries and raspberry vinaigrette; Greek yoghurt with raspberries, popcorn.

Wednesday: wrap with garden vegetable spread, spinach, olives, cheese and carrots (and turkey, which she forgot to buy), wheat thins, carrots, hummus, grapes.

Thursday:  salad with black beans, corn, red and yellow peppers and lime juice (and cilantro), baked scoops and salsa.

Friday: pita with hummus, lettuce, tomatoes and mozzarella cheese, watermelon and hard-boiled eggs.

content.body:
Monday: peanut butter / jelly sandwich, apple, cellery, carrots and ranch sauce.

Tuesday: spinach and lettuce salad with strawberries and raspberry vinaigrette; Greek yoghurt with raspberries, popcorn.

Wednesday: wrap with garden vegetable spread, spinach, olives, cheese and carrots (and turkey, which she forgot to buy), wheat thins, carrots, hummus, grapes.

Thursday: salad with black beans, corn, red and yellow peppers and lime juice (and cilantro), baked scoops and salsa.

Friday: pita with hummus, lettuce, tomatoes and mozzarella cheese, watermelon and hard-boiled eggs.

items.content:
To be able to do all the assignments correctly, you need to know some words and sentences.
For each theme there are word lists ready in Wozzol, with which you can practice:

Woordenlijst: My timetable hv12
  • Study the vocabulary. (10 minutes)
  • Do the exercise.

Tip!
There are many ways to study vocabulary. You can read the words aloud or copy them. The most important rule is never to spend more than 10 minutes studying words. Every minute you spend longer is a waste of time.

content.body:
Fill in the correct words. There are three extra words.
Choose from: art - geography - history - home economics - languages - lunch box - lunch break - maths - Monday - P.E. - period - timetable - tutor.

  1. I still need to check my to see which subject is next.
  2. Do we have English in the first or the second today?
  3. During my , I often go to the supermarket to buy a salad or a sandwich.
  4. I'm actually really good at , so if you need help solving that equation, just ask me.
  5. My brother doesn't like , except Spanish, which is easy because we speak it at home.
  6. Today in we learnt about slavery in the colonies.
  7. We had a choice between baseball and football for today.
  8. I am going to learn how to prepare a black-bean salad in .
  9. Funnily enough, our teacher is not actually very good at drawing.
  10. Didn't they teach you in where England is on the map?

items.content:
Om te vertellen over dingen die al zijn gebeurd, gebruik je in het Engels de past simple.

We waited for an hour. - We hebben een uur gewacht.
I looked really good. - Ik zag er heel goed uit.
Did you brush your teeth? - Heb je je tanden gepoetst?
Sam didn't like the salad. - Sam vond de salade niet lekker.

Bestudeer uit de Kennisbank het onderdeel Past simple - regelmatige werkwoorden. Denk na over deze vragen:

  • Wat zet je achter een (regelmatig) werkwoord om er een past simple van te maken?
  • Maakt het uit welk persoonlijk voornaamwoord (I, you, he, ...) ervoor staat?
  • Welk woordje gebruik je aan het begin van een vragende zin in de past simple?
Past simple - regelmatige werkwoorden
Do the excercise.

content.body:
Fill in the correct forms of the verbs. Use the past simple.

  1. He (walk) to school yesterday.
  2. My mother (worry) when Peter didn't come home last night.
  3. He (live) in New York in 2009.
  4. I (receive) a letter last week.
  5. My brother (dip) everything in apple sauce when he was little.
  6. We (dance) until four in the morning.

Fill in the correct forms of the verbs. Use the past simple.

  1. Humeyra (work) hard last weekend?
  2. the girls (apologise) for their bad behaviour?
  3. you (like) History when you were a teenager?
  4. I (miss) the game?
  5. we (fly) to Spain in 2019?

Fill in the correct forms of the verbs. Use the past simple.

  1. Seamus (not - drop) his keys. I've got them.
  2. My father (not - accept) the gift he was offered.
  3. You (not - play) here yesterday, right?
  4. I (not - mind) the noise, but the mess was awful.
  5. We (not - want) a puppy. We got a dog from the shelter instead.

items.content:
Your school day

Have two conversation with a classmate. Use the Speech cards.

Practise your conversation at least twice.
Persoon A: Speech card - persoon A.
Persoon B: Speech card - persoon B.

Preparation

  1. Prepare for both roles.
  2. Write down a couple of words and phrases to help you during the conversations.
  3. Practise both your conversations at least twice. Switch roles for the second conversation.
  4. Pay special attention to the correct use of question words. Check the theory in the Toolbox if necessary.

Having the conversations

  1. Find another pair to work with.
  2. Have your two conversations.
  3. Ask your classmates to write down feedback for you.
  4. Next, let them have their conversation and write down feedback for them. Pay special attention to the correct use of question words.
  5. Discuss what went well and what you can do better next time.

A diary entry about your timetable

You have studied Jason's timetable and you have talked about timetables in Speaking. Now you are going to write an entry in your diary about your own timetable.

  • Give a short description of your timetable.
    • Do you have long or short days?
    • What are some of your subjects? Name at least three and say how often and/or when you've got them.
    • When is your lunch break?
  • Explain what your favourite and least favourite subjects are. Give reasons.
  • Give your opinion about your timetable. Support your opinion with three examples from your timetable. For example, are there days which start too early or finish too late? Are there days with only your least favourite subjects? Etcetera.
  • Describe your lunch breaks. What do you do, what do you eat and where does your lunch come from?
  • Finally, explain who your tutor is and what you think of them.
  • Ask your teacher how many words you have to use.

What have you learnt in this double period?
Answer the following questions:

  • What was the easiest part of this lesson?
  • What did you already know?
  • What was the most difficult part?
  • What was new to you in this lesson?
  • Are there things you don't quite understand yet? How are you going to deal with them?
  • What do you need to ask your teacher?

The subject of this double period is back to school.

  • Make groups of three or four.
  • Discuss these questions in English with your group:
    • How did you feel on your first day at secondary school?
    • What did you already know about your new school?
    • Who did you already know there?
  • Together, make a mindmap with 15-20 words that have to do with the first day of secondary school. Use four topics for the 'arms'. One of them should be 'emotions'.

First day at school

You are going to read a text in which Katy describes her experiences at a new school.

  • Read the text.
  • While reading, think about the following question:
    • Was Katy's first year at her new school a positive or a negative experience? Look for examples in the text which support your opinion.

My experiences starting secondary school
The new school term has begun and lots of you have gone to secondary school for the first time. In her report Press Packer Katy shares her experiences of starting secondary school and offers some useful advice.


"I started a new school a year ago and I can't believe how quickly the year went!
I wasn't that nervous on my first day, I was really looking forward to it. I knew a bit about what to expect because I had an older sister at the same school.

It will be fine!
For anyone who's starting a new school, don't worry. The stories that you hear aren't usually true - I don't know anyone who's been bog-washed!
I've met lots of new people and made loads of new friends since I started.
I thought the work would suddenly get really hard but it was just like primary school really. I also thought that I'd be flooded with homework but the amount I got in my first year was quite easy to handle.

Katy's tips
Here's my advice for anyone who's worried about going to a new school:

  • Relax and think about all the positives of moving to secondary school
  • Don't be shy, introduce yourself to people!
  • Be yourself, don't try to brag because people might think you're big-headed

Good luck!"
Katy, 13, Edinburgh

bron: CBBC Newsround

Do the exercises.

Do the excercises.

content.body:
Fill in the correct forms of the verbs. Use the past simple.

  1. The lesson (to start) 5 minutes ago. You're late.
  2. I (to work) very hard on that essay.
  3. Jay (to copy) my homework, Miss!
  4. They (to listen) to music on their phones instead of paying attention.
  5. (you - to check) your timetable?
  6. (Daryl - to play) a computer game last night?
  7. (Amy - to hand in) her project this morning?

  9. You (not - to look) tired when I saw you last week.
  10. We (not - to wait) for him very long.

Fill in the correct forms of the verbs. Use the past simple.

  2. (Jerry - to miss) P.E. last week?
  3. I (to introduce) myself to everyone who seemed nice.
  4. You (not - to like) History when you started school, did you, Dad?
  5. The car (to stop) just in time.
  6. I (not - to walk) to school this morning. I took the bus.
  7. My best friend (to live) in Boston in 2022.
  8. (they - to ask) the teacher for help?
  9. The teachers (not - to listen) to us, which was frustrating.
  10. (you - to watch) YouTube during Geography?

items.content:
My first day at school

Have a conversation with a classmate. Use the description below.

Preparation

  1. Take a few minutes to prepare.
  2. Write down a couple of words and phrases to help you during the conversation.
  3. You will be asked to use the past simple correctly. Have another look at the theory in the Toolbox if necessary.

Having the conversations

  1. Find another pair to work with.
  2. Have your conversation.
  3. Ask your classmates to write down feedback for you.
  4. Next, let them have their conversation and write down feedback for them. Pay special attention to the correct use of the past simple.
  5. Discuss what went well and what you can do better next time.

Je kunt je je eerste dag op de middelbare school vast nog wel herinneren. Hoe heb jij dat ervaren? Praat over je ervaringen met je klasgenoot.

Praat in elk geval over de volgende onderwerpen:

  • Hoe voelde je je op je eerste schooldag?
  • Wat wist je van tevoren van je nieuwe school, en wie kende je er al?
  • Valt de middelbare school tot nu toe mee of tegen?
  • Is de middelbare school makkelijker of moeilijker dan de basisschool?
  • Hoe gaat het op sociaal gebied? Kun je goed opschieten met andere leerlingen en met de leraren?
  • Heb je nog tips voor leerlingen die volgend jaar op de middelbare school beginnen?

Starting a new school

You have read a text about starting a new school. Now you are going to write an article for new students.

  • Start with a short introduction. What was your first day at secondary school like?
  • Describe the differences between primary and secondary school.
  • Give at least 3 pieces of useful advice for new students. If possible, use tips that have really helped you personally in your first year, or that you wish you had known about before starting secondary school.
  • For a conclusion, wish the new students luck.
  • Ask your teacher how many words you have to use.
  • Pay special attention to the correct use of the past simple.

What have you learnt in this double period?
Answer the following questions:

  • What was the easiest part of this lesson?
  • What did you already know?
  • What was the most difficult part?
  • What was new to you in this lesson?
  • Are there things you don't quite understand yet? How are you going to deal with them?
  • What do you need to ask your teacher?

The subject of this double period is school subjects.

  • Make groups of three or four.
  • Discuss these questions in English with your group:
    • What subjects do you take at school? Write down the English names of all the subjects in your timetable.
    • What other subjects do you know? Write them down.
    • What is your favourite subject? Why?
    • What is the most difficult subject? Why?

items.content:
My favourite subject

You are going to read two texts about favourite subjects.

  • Read the texts.
  • While reading, think about the following question:
    • Do Sally and Maria like school? How can you tell?

Sally Reyes
Guess what my favourite subject is in school? It's P.E.! I like it because it's fun and competitive. P.E. is a time to have fun with friends, and it helps me to stay healthy.
Another subject I like in school is computer lab. I feel relaxed just sitting down, ready to listen and ready to start my assignment or activity. I'm always ready to go in regular classes, too, by the way, but I'm always extra motivated for computer lab. I just like digital assignments better than learning from a book.
School can be hard work, but some subjects can be fun, which makes it easier to deal with. So what are your favourites subjects?

Maria Beas
First of all, I don't have one favourite subject, I like too many!
One of them is maths. I love taking five-minute tests. It's not easy, but I like a challange. You have to finish 100 problems in five minutes. I also love getting back tests to see if I did OK!
I also love science, because you learn something new every day. My favourite part is when they bring in animals and tell us what they do.
I especially love art, because you get to express your feelings. When you're happy you can paint a flower or a rainbow. If you're upset or angry, you can paint a thundercloud with lightning. I guess you get the idea. Well, anyway, thank you for reading my story. Hey, reading! That's another subject I like.



Do the exercises.

3. regular
4. motivated
5. a challenge
6. express your feelings
7. rainbow
8. lightning

4. motivated gemotiveerd Het lijkt op het Nederlandse woord en dat past in de context.

8. lightning bliksem Dit teken je bij een donderwolk als je boos bent, dus het moet wel bliksem zijn.

prompt.body:

  7. Wat bedoelt Maria met 'I guess you get the idea'?
  8. Wat vindt Maria naast wiskunde, exacte vakken en beeldende vorming nog meer leuk op school?

  8. Lezen.

Tip!
There are many ways to study vocabulary. You can read the words aloud or copy them. The most important rule is never to spend more than 10 minutes studying words. Every minute you spend longer is a waste of time.

Fill in the correct forms of the verbs. Use the past simple.

  1. Django (to cycle) to school yesterday because the bus was late.
  2. (Bri - to work) at the baker's last year?

items.content:
An interview about school

Have an interview with a classmate. Use the description below.

Preparation

  1. Prepare for both roles: interviewer and interviewee.
  2. Think of five school-related questions you can ask your classmate. Pay special attention to the correct use of question words. Use at least three different ones.
  3. Write down a couple of words and phrases to help you in your interview.

Having the interview

  1. Find another pair to work with.
  2. Have your interview.
  3. Ask your classmates to write down feedback for you.
  4. Next, let them have their discussion and write down feedback for them. Pay special attention to the correct use of question words.
  5. Discuss what went well and what you can do better next time.

Je interviewt een klasgenoot over school: wat diegene er wel en niet leuk aan vindt en waarom, wat de moeilijke en makkelijke vakken zijn, hoe je daarmee omgaat enzovoorts.

It should be banned!

You are going to write an opinion piece about your least favourite subject.

  • Start with an introduction. Which subject do you feel should be banned?
  • Give at least three reasons why it should be banned.
  • Describe your past experiences with the subject. Pay special attention to the correct use of the past simple.
  • Explain what is good about the subject and what you could need it for in the future.
  • Think either of another way you can learn that skill, or think of a reason why it's unnecessary.
  • Finish your opinion piece appropriately.
  • Ask your teacher how many words you have to use.

What have you learnt in this double period?
Answer the following questions:

  • What was the easiest part of this lesson?
  • What did you already know?
  • What was the most difficult part?
  • What was new to you in this lesson?
  • Are there things you don't quite understand yet? How are you going to deal with them?
  • What do you need to ask your teacher?

Je hebt de blokken van het thema 'School' doorgewerkt.
Tijd voor de Finishing touch.
Je vindt hier één extra opdracht.
Werk samen met een aantal klasgenoten.
Maak daarna de D-toets en beantwoord de evaluatievragen.

Succes.

In this theme, you are going to create a virtual tour of your school.
There is an example of a virtual tour of a school on Woodlands: projectbritain.com.
This tour is a virtual tour with pictures.
You can also make a virtual tour of your school with a videocamera:


Product:
A powerpoint or Prezi-presentation of your virtual tour of about four minutes per group (with spoken and written English). For the virtual tour in pictures your presentation has pictures in it, for the virtual tour with a videocamera your presentation has video fragments in it.
The virtual tour can be about for example students' experiences
(with interviews), IT facilities at your school, teachers at your school, general facilities at your school et cetera.
Now, read the procedure and get started!

Procedure for virtual tour in pictures:

  • Divide the class into groups of (about) four students.
  • In your groups, think about what you want to show in your virtual tour and what you need to do to show this.
  • Divide the tasks in your group. Set deadlines and schedule meetings (if necessary).
  • Prepare your presentation.
  • Present your product.

Procedure for virtual tour with a videocamera:

  • Divide the class into groups of (about) four students.
  • In your groups, think about what you want to show in your virtual tour and what you need to do to show this.
  • Divide the tasks in your group. Set deadlines and schedule meetings
    (if necessary).
  • Prepare your presentation.
  • Present your product.
Test je kennis. Maak de diagnostische toets.

content.body:
In the sentences below, has the Past simple tense been used correctly?
Choose correct or wrong.

  1. We travelled to Germany last year. correct / wrong
  2. She didn't brushed her teeth this morning. correct / wrong
  3. Did they apologised after the fight? correct / wrong

Fill in the correct form Past simple.

  1. He (live) in New York in 2009.
  2. This morning we (talk) about it.
  3. My brother (wash) his car last month.

prompt.body:
You are going to read a story about School uniforms. After reading the story, answer the question below.

School Uniform
Most schools in England require children to wear a school uniform.

Boys

  • Long grey or black trousers (shorts may be worn in the Summer)
  • White shirt
  • School tie (optional in most primary schools)
  • Jumper or sweater with the school logo on. The colour is the choice of the schools.
  • Black shoes.​

Girls
As above. Girls may wear skirts.
During the summer term girls often wear summer school dresses.

Why wear a uniform?

  • When we go on a school trip we all look the same and so can't get lost.
  • Stops kids worrying about what to wear each day.
  • Everyone is equal.
  • Parents don't have to shop for expensive and varied wardrobes for their children to keep up with or show-off to other children.
  • Wearing a uniform instills a sense of pride and discipline in students.​

Why not to wear a uniform?
Uniforms deny students their right to personal identity and self-expression.


What do girls often wear during the summer?

content.body: dresses
trousers
hats

(Personal question:) What do you prefer: wearing/ not wearing a uniform? Why?

values.value:
Example:
No: I don’t want to wear a uniform because it is not good for my personal identity.
Yes: I want to belong to a group (to feel stronger).

prompt.body:
Make a list of six subjects (= vakken) you are studying at school.
What is your favourite subject? Put the most favourite on top of the list!

content.body:
Example answer:

  1. English
  2. Chemistry
  3. Maths
  4. Dutch
  5. History
  6. Geography

prompt.body:
School newspapers
Having a newspaper or magazine can also make your school a better place.
By letting people know what's going on, you make it easier to organise clubs and events.
Papers also help people talk about the things that they are unhappy with and that can lead to changes in the way a school works. You can also learn about the different jobs involved and work out which one you might be interested in. To realize a school newspaper you need volunteers (= vrijwilligers).

What jobs are there to make a newspaper?

content.body:
Photos are great for attracting readers to your stories. The quality can be a bit dodgy if you are photocopying your paper, so it's good to have someone who knows what they are doing with a digital camera.

You probably also need to lighten the pictures some picture edit software before you paste them into your DTP package.
You could get someone good at art to do a cartoon for each issue of the paper. They could even do a comic strip

Someone needs to decide how the paper should look. They can use artwork and design skills to get the pages looking really interesting. They will probably be pretty good with graphics packages on the computer.
He/she is the boss of the paper - they decide what sort of stories it should cover and let the staff know who is doing what.

They write news stories. That could mean going to school events and coming back with a story, or maybe going to get information from several people and piecing it together to make a story that explains things clearly to readers.
A big sports fan who would go along to school matches and write you a report. They need to know the rules and scoring systems. Someone into lots of different sports would be ideal.
Editor
Cartoonist
Reporters
Designer
Photographer
Sports writer

items.content:
You started this theme you with a test in the section Need to know.

  • Do this test again.
  • Are your results better than the first time?

At the end of each double period you answered evaluation questions. Use these answers to answer the following questions:

  • What new things did you learn?
  • Which assignment was the best one to learn from?
  • Are you able to do what you have to do?
  • How did you get on doing the assignments?

Timing
In the introduction of each double period there is an indication of the amount of time you need to do the activity.

  • What do you think of this timing?

Group work

  • What do you think of working in a group?
  • Did every group member do the same amount of work?

Project

  • What did you think of the project?

Verderkijker

De Verderkijker biedt bij dit thema passende externe linkjes naar uitleg, oefenmateriaal of filmpjes. Voor het thema School zijn de volgende items geselecteerd.

Grammatica - Vraagwoorden (questions)

  • www.youtube.com
    Videouitleg.
  • www.grammar.cl
    Meerkeuze oefening. Klik het juiste antwoord aan.
  • www.tolearnenglish.com
    Meerkeuzevragen. Maak de zin compleet.

Grammatica - Past simple (regelmatige ww)

  • www.grammar.cl/english/past-tense.htm
    Theorieuitleg met voorbeelden in present and past simple.
  • oefeningenengels.classy.be
    Invuloefening met past simple.
  • www.youtube.com
    Videouitleg over Past simple Verbs Ending.

Lezen - Schrijven - Luisteren - Kijken - Spreken:

  • www.languageguide.org
    Klik op de plaatjes en luister naar de uitspraak van de woorden.
  • learnenglishteens.britishcouncil.org
    Bekijk de train timetable en maak een of meer 'Check your understanding'-oefeningen.
  • www.esl-lab.com
    Luister naar de audio 'A day at school' (onder 2. Listening Exercises).
    Beantwoord de 5 vragen.
  • www.elllo.org
    Luister naar de audio over 'School life'.
    Doe de Vocabulary Quiz en de Comprehension Quiz.


In de Verderkijker wordt gebruik gemaakt van beeld- en filmmateriaal dat beschikbaar is op internet. Bij het gebruik zijn we uitgegaan van fair use. Mocht u vragen/opmerkingen hebben, of constateert u een niet-werkende link, horen wij dit natuurlijk graag. Dit kan via onze helpdesk
